where  "the executioner and her way of life" is set feels loosely built.P.S first review every so forgive me for any mistakes that i have made,', 'I got curious about this show once I heard about the premise, and opening episodes promised an interesting build up, however it falls apart pretty fast. Let\'s get dive into it. Without spoilers.It starts off with an idea of a world that has been "invaded" by Isekai protagonists for a long time so much so, that it became a nuisance for those living in it and led to some catastrophic moments. What was nice about the beginning is that it sort of starts as a typical Isekai only to turn it on it\'s head. And that was enjoyable to watch.I enjoy the design of MC...and the idea of them using Ether or whatever it was as "magic" for both combat and appliances, they way it\'s used and designed is rather pleasant. But since story revolves around two main and two sidekick characters and their interactions, your overall satisfaction depends on whether you find those interactions interesting/funny/cute enough to keep watching or not. I wasn\'t all that amused by it so it was rather bland to watch.Action scenes are fine, but as there is not enough connection between me as a viewer and characters involved, since I\'m barely acquainted with them, it lacks impact for me. Ok, so character X died, I know this character from a 1.5 minute flashback and 2 interactions, why should I care whatsoever? They didn\'t even try to show how it impacted the character involved with said character.By the end of Episode 7, while watching an additional portion of hugs, bathtub fan service (again) I understood that I feel bored watching this and started skipping such useless parts to get to anything more interesting. While doing so turned out only about 3-4 minutes had anything meaningful happening.With that said I have to drop it for been boring and it\'s sad, as there was potential. and the idea of them using Ether or whatever it was as "magic" for both combat and appliances, they way it\'s used and designed is rather pleasant. While doing so turned out only about 3-4 minutes had anything meaningful happening.With that said I have to drop it for been boring and it\'s sad, as there was potential.', 'First of all, this is a terrible “against the grain” type of isekai anime.  I enjoyed the art and sound during the action scenes, but the story/char was really bad.Understand, this is straight up yuri and the hate for men characters is there.  The story was terrible as it felt like an loose adaption of Minority Report where the innocent are judged and executed based on assumptions which the movie later showed that those assumptions were just one path taken.In Virgin Road, innocent isekai are summoned and summarily executed for just existing based on what they may or may not do.  The...main char has no development and the world building is mediocre at best.Just another man hating show trying way to hard to be something different. main char has no development and the world building is mediocre at best.Just another man hating show trying way to hard to be something different.', "Something like Mitsuki being revived to take revenge on those who summoned him and seeking vengeance against Menou would make the story more interesting. However, the narrative only explores how the executioner goes about their tasks, or something like that. Mitsuki should be the main character who not only brings about the destruction of the world but also initiates a transformation, ensuring that executioners and nobles cease to exist. I'm disappointed that Mitsuki is more or less like Nanao Nakajima, who was unable to do anything with his life taken away without his understanding. Some people will say he's not the main character in the...first place, but he'd be cooler if given a chance for revenge and to change the world so that no one will experience the absurdity that he encountered. If you liked Talentless Nana, then watch this. But if you're not into yuri-ish types of anime, then I don't recommend it. first place, but he'd be cooler if given a chance for revenge and to change the world so that no one will experience the absurdity that he encountered. If you liked Talentless Nana, then watch this. But if you're not into yuri-ish types of anime, then I don't recommend it.", 'This is coming from a lesbian perspective, but I relatively enjoyed this. It definitely needs a second season in order to see if I like it or not, but it definitely looks promising.Story 7/10I really like the premise and thought it was an interesting twist on the isekai genre. The first episode was amazing and really sucked me in, but it kinda went downhill after that. The last arc in the season is what brought up the score. The ending of the season was really well done and makes me excited for season 2.Art 5/10Very average, cheap anime art style. I noticed that they reused...a lot of frames, especially toward the end.Characters 7/10I like the main characters, but they do fall into basic archetypes of the isekai genre. Some red flags for me were the constant use of "friends" between the two female leads, and I swear if they queer bait I will be rioting. Overall, I just want to see some good sapphic love, and that is kinda what I got. I just hope they make it more romantic in future seasons.Overall 7/10Pretty average isekai/fantasy overall, but added points for the gl. I really hope this anime gets a second season because I think this series can become a lot better over time and with some plot and character development. I recommend this to those who enjoy fantasy/magic environments, like gl, or are fans of shows like The Seven Deadly Sins (when it was good). a lot of frames, especially toward the end.Characters 7/10I like the main characters, but they do fall into basic archetypes of the isekai genre. Some red flags for me were the constant use of "friends" between the two female leads, and I swear if they queer bait I will be rioting. Overall, I just want to see some good sapphic love, and that is kinda what I got. I just hope they make it more romantic in future seasons.Overall 7/10Pretty average isekai/fantasy overall, but added points for the gl. I really hope this anime gets a second season because I think this series can become a lot better over time and with some plot and character development. I recommend this to those who enjoy fantasy/magic environments, like gl, or are fans of shows like The Seven Deadly Sins (when it was good).', 'One of the risks you take going into a light novel adaptation these days is whether or not the anime is just going to end up as a glorified commercial for the books. Y\'all know what I mean; it\'s when you have cool characters in a great story that run smack into a cliffhanger that may not ever be resolved with another season, which means that your only options are to seek out the books (and that\'s if you\'re lucky enough to have localized versions of the books to turn to). All of this is to say that I never expected the ending of The...Executioner and Her Way of Life to feel especially conclusive, but I sure was preparing myself to at least be underwhelmed. Thankfully, "The Duo\'s Journey" does a great job of wrapping up the current storyline while still leaving room for lots more intrigue and tragedy down the road, which is basically everything you could ask for in a finale for a season that may or may not ever get a proper follow up.Granted, the last episode did so much work escalating the Pandaemonium conflict that the only thing that this finale really had to do was dispatch the giant centipede monster and give each of our heroines something to do in the meantime. The action scenes have been hit-or-miss in this second half of the season, though, so I\'m happy to report that Executioner doesn\'t fumble it in the endzone. The CGI model that is used for almost any of the non-close-up shots of Pandaemonium doesn\'t look amazing, but it\'s good enough, and I\'ve warmed up to the design since last time. Bug!Pandaemonium has a mouth that is a little too Muppety to be threatening (and that\'s coming from a Muppet superfan), but it\'s still a fun fight. Ashuna gets to hit stuff really good, Akari gets to shoot stuff with her vague time powers, and Menou gets to use Ashuna\'s sword and the power of Akari\'s love to turn Pandaemonium into mush. Fun stuff.Then there\'s the half of the episode that exists to wrap up loose ends and remind us that this was just the second story in a multi-volume light novel series, and that there\'s plenty more to come in the future. Not every beat works; I\'m especially puzzled at the interaction between Menou and Sicilia about Flare. I don\'t know if Sicilia had more to do in the books, but she\'s barely registered as a character in the show, so the scene mostly felt like a ham-fisted reminder that Flare does indeed exist, and that she may even do something relevant to the plot someday. I also wish we\'d gotten more than a throwaway scene when it comes to Menou trying to figure out what the hell was up with Akari\'s sudden shift in personality and power level that has just as suddenly disappeared now that Pandaemonium is gone. It comes across as the author writing themselves into a corner with the True Akari reveal and handwaving an easy solution so they can save the better scenes for later.Still, I\'d say more about the finale worked than did not. I loved the final interaction between Menou and Pandaemonium, and not just for the excellently creepy sound design on Pandaemonium\'s voice. The reveal that the Sword of Salt might be the one way for Menou to kill Akari gives the next phase of the plot a much more concrete goal. It also gives Momo a great moment to end the season on, since she got very little to do in these last few episodes; I\'m very much looking forward to seeing how her own relationship with Akari evolves in the future. Also, can I just say how much I appreciate the little coda we got between Pandaemonium and Manon? The reveal that they are siblings is fine, yeah, but what I really dig is that Manon didn\'t just get unceremoniously chest exploded for good. It makes me a lot more forgiving of how the story handled her backstory info-dump knowing that she and her little sis have both survived to wreak more chaos together.I\'ll be honest: I have a really hard time getting into light novels, since I\'ve never been impressed with the writing in any of the ones that I\'ve read before, and I haven\'t heard great things about the quality of Executioner\'s prose, specifically. Still, it says something that I liked the anime version of The Executioner and Her Way of Life enough that I\'m halfway considering giving the novels a shot anyways. It wasn\'t a perfect series, but it\'s fascinating characters and world were wrapped up in a genuinely compelling story, and that\'s more than enough to earn my seal of approval. All we can do now is pray that there is just a little bit of justice in this world. If a godforsaken curse like The Fruit of Evolution can get a second season, then there is no reason that Executioner can\'t get one as well. All we can do now is pray that there is just a little bit of justice in this world. If a godforsaken curse like The Fruit of Evolution can get a second season, then there is no reason that Executioner can\'t get one as well.', "Spoilers ahead!I’m really struggling in rating this show because emotionally I’m pretty sold on the concept (or what I’ve idealised it to be) but objectively I’ve found way too many problems with the story to feel like I could recommend it to a friend, so I’d settle for 7 instead of 8.Initially I had good expectations. The trailer looked fresh and promising: Isekai that doesn’t have a reincarnated weeb as MC? Badass-looking, all-female cast with understated romance? Let's go!!I was blown away by the twist in the first episode and the overall dynamics until the third. The action was good and the flashbacks had this...awesome lore vibe to them so I was just hyped, like “this is the anime of the season!” kind of hype.Then I got the third episode where they take the train ride, and it all went down the drain. The pacing got slow and stayed like that until the end of the season, the dialogues never took off and stayed tropey and empty and the action sequences got suddenly limp and watered down, as if they were trying to stretch the story inside one episode where half of it would have been enough. When I thought a climax was approaching they’d just speak their lines slower to fill up some more minutes and let things take the most obvious route.Maybe it’s the restricted cast that makes it difficult to keep things dynamic action-wise? Then a good writer would focus on the interaction between characters, with real dialogues and exposition. But, nah, let’s go shopping and bitch over why you are buying that ribbon for your long time friend and not for me, a random girl you’ve just met and you’re secretly supposed to kill!Akari starts out like a harmless airhead but increasingly turns into a needy spoiled brat that likes to hog Menou’s attention and cause drama for no reason at all. We are given a glimpse of her redeeming backstory far too late in the show, and even with that knowledge it’s hard to justify her childish codependent behaviour.Paradoxically, Momo ends up on the better side, because even as a love-addicted psycho she still shows more sense than Akari and many times comes to take the role of the straight man.Menou on the other hand is almost funny in her sheltered naivety and how she works as a magnet-pacifier of the triangle. Her lack of personality and ductility is what defines her and it works, but what happens after the midseason climax with the archbishop incident makes it pretty clear her character is not handled properly. You receive massive revelations about this girl whom you’re somehow connected with by fate but instead of talking it out or having a change in your interactions with her, well, you just carry on as if nothing happened, because you just gotta complete your mission, right? Right. What mission again?Too little info is given about whatever else is going on in the world or simply how the Church reacted to ahem, the Archbishop blowing up. Ashuna also stays in the backburner and there’s not one glimpse of a reason provided for why she keeps showing up other than, well, because she just damn feels like it. The focus seems to be just on the love cocoon between Dumb and Dumber, but even that is not convincing.Akari is outrageously flirty out of the blue, which could work as a love-comedy expedient sometimes, but she’s always blown off by Menou’s icy cluelessness as if it was a children's tantrum. Thankfully Momo at least is able to see what could be happening but yeah, in twelve episodes nothing remotely yuri ever happens, just a set of cliche suggestive moments that resolve in goofy comedy. Not a single proper blushing face, no tension, just a lot of head pats from Menou as her seal of sisterly camaraderie. Towards the end it becomes almost heartwarming as Menou relaxes a bit but the romance tag is totally a bait, which is disappointing, especially given the massive shipping potential of those beautiful OP and ED. Hopefully something substantial will come up in later seasons.Speaking of OP, I love how good the animation is and how sometimes that is reflected in the episodes as well, with good photography and even sakuga in some battles and critical moments like the flashbacks. Unfortunately many other times the quality slips towards the lower end and I remember witnessing a whole episode made up of basically just four frames and looping animation for entire minutes. Heartbreaking.Sound-wise the BGM is good in that it mostly complements the situations nicely whether they be ambiguous and sneaky or fiery and dramatic, although there was not a wide range of different themes. Sound effects are juicy and materialise well the power of magic and enchantments.Overall, it feels like I was tricked into buying a cosmetic product with awesome sensual packaging but zero actual effectiveness, that I nevertheless keep on putting on every morning because I want to hope one day it’ll magically start working.Weird analogy aside, this is a show that could have been great with its original, enticing premises, but ended up average and unsatisfying due to poor writing and lack of depth.Maybe it’s just very very slow?I want to hope so. awesome lore vibe to them so I was just hyped, like “this is the anime of the season!” kind of hype.Then I got the third episode where they take the train ride, and it all went down the drain. The pacing got slow and stayed like that until the end of the season, the dialogues never took off and stayed tropey and empty and the action sequences got suddenly limp and watered down, as if they were trying to stretch the story inside one episode where half of it would have been enough. When I thought a climax was approaching they’d just speak their lines slower to fill up some more minutes and let things take the most obvious route.Maybe it’s the restricted cast that makes it difficult to keep things dynamic action-wise? Then a good writer would focus on the interaction between characters, with real dialogues and exposition. But, nah, let’s go shopping and bitch over why you are buying that ribbon for your long time friend and not for me, a random girl you’ve just met and you’re secretly supposed to kill!Akari starts out like a harmless airhead but increasingly turns into a needy spoiled brat that likes to hog Menou’s attention and cause drama for no reason at all. We are given a glimpse of her redeeming backstory far too late in the show, and even with that knowledge it’s hard to justify her childish codependent behaviour.Paradoxically, Momo ends up on the better side, because even as a love-addicted psycho she still shows more sense than Akari and many times comes to take the role of the straight man.Menou on the other hand is almost funny in her sheltered naivety and how she works as a magnet-pacifier of the triangle. Staff has ever done. I remember finishing the first episode of this, going to MAL to add it to watch, and then having an open mouth like that one pikachu meme when I saw they animated this. But to dive into the anime itself, it loses people really fast. It's an isekai that tries desperately to come off as being different but falls right back into the same basic formula. This is pretty much an isekai yuri but the people being isekai'd are actually detrimental to this society due to their destructive powers. Once...you realize that the plot revolves around this one character having to eventually die, it gets boring. I often don't understand the motives of any of the characters, and when I do I'm just like this is stupid. Oh well, I hope JC Staff can keep up this animation quality in future projects. you realize that the plot revolves around this one character having to eventually die, it gets boring. I often don't understand the motives of any of the characters, and when I do I'm just like this is stupid. Oh well, I hope JC Staff can keep up this animation quality in future projects.", "The Executioner and Her Way of Life is the logical conclusion of the isekai genre. There is nothing subversive about it. It is simply a story about what might truly happen if socially malformed Japanese teenagers were given godlike powers and sent to a world that does not want them. At the heart of that story is a girl who has been put in the position of needing to deal with the problems that these otherworlders cause. She is a hard motherfucker by necessity, because who would want the job of killing innocent children who haven't had the chance to abuse their powers yet? No...one except the psychopathic, and she is one of the more sane characters in the series. She is a troubled character that faces many compelling choices that test the fabric of who she is as a person. You cannot ask for a better protagonist.But Executioner is more than just an interesting concept with a compelling main character. It is also a fully realized fantasy world with rules and history that are unique to its story. Most isekai fall back on the well-known rules and world of Dungeons and Dragons. You might even say they wholly copy the work J. R. R. Tolkien has already done. It means the storyteller doesn't have to spend as much time on exposition, but it also makes all isekai look the same and fills them with similar creatures, systems of magic, and plot points.It is encouraging to see that almost everything within Executioner is its own. There are no elves or goblins thrown in the viewer's face (though whether these typical fantasy creatures and their familiar counterparts exist in this world is not yet clear). The magic system goes beyond simple magic circles that sprout easily from the character's hands. Magic is bound to the level of etheric power in a person, their ability to control it, and their understanding of the scriptural tool that can harness that power. Even better, the magic within Executioner is not limited to a single system. The otherworlders come to this new world with powers of their own that have different rules and dangers. Lastly, there is no tired and omnipresent demon lord waiting to be killed at the end of the series. Instead, there are morally gray human organizations with members and leaders who alternatively strive for a better world or to better their own circumstances. There are terrifying and unknowable monsters lurking in the background which could only exist in this story.And of course, what would any anime be without a full cast of interesting and fun characters. Menou is more than just a child murderer that murders children. Akari is more than just a bumbling foreigner with powers that could destroy the world. Momo is more than just a yandere lesbian that wants to jump Menou's bones. Ashuna is more than just a spoiled princess, looking to escape her privileged status. The villains are numerous and manage to get by without twirling their mustaches. All of them, even the near-mindless monsters, have unique and understandable motivations. Everyone comes with layers that go deep, and it is exciting to see those layers peeled back.As for the production side of the story, the art and sound are mostly serviceable and never subpar. The visuals never drop below the quality line that would distract you from the story, but they also do not rise to the glistening heights of some high-production quality anime. The music is likely to go largely unnoticed except for a few standout moments where it can swell into something special.All-in-all, The Executioner and Her Way of Life deserves to stand with the greats of isekai like Re: Zero, Ascendance of a Bookworm, or Mushoku Tensai. The tellers behind this story understand the genre and what makes it interesting and they are willing to experiment to make something unique and compelling. one except the psychopathic, and she is one of the more sane characters in the series. The tellers behind this story understand the genre and what makes it interesting and they are willing to experiment to make something unique and compelling.", 'When the Girls Love community got word that The Executioner and Her Way of Life was going to get animated, there seemed be pretty subtle cheers, due to the fact that the source material didn\'t really lean into much in the way of the romantic feelings.  And it\'s true.  So you kind of have to watch this series with that mindset, otherwise I feel like you\'ll be left disappointed.Story: The Executioner and Her Way of Life sets place in a fantasy world where multiple citizens from Japan are summoned by the current world\'s king.  These individuals have special powers after they are...summoned, known as Special Concepts, but if the king deems them useless for his purposes, he basically abandons them and throws them into the open world.  Those people are known as the Lost Ones.  However, since they enter the world and are essentially left to fend for themselves, they have no real knowledge of the world, or the powers they have just obtained.  This ends up having dire consequences on the world.  Enter Menou, who is tasked to lead the Lost Ones to one of the churches, where she then executes them before their powers can run haywire on her world.  The one problem that she runs into is that a Lost One known as Akari Tokitou enters the world, and Menou literally cannot kill her, due to her unique ability.Right off the bat, I really like the world that The Executioner and Her Way of Life has set up here.  Menou and a few other characters wield scriptures, special books that enhance their magical abilities.  This gives our characters access to spells with unpredictable results to assist them in battle.  One of my favourites is when Menou throws her dagger and uses a Gale spell to literally create large wind pressures within the target she stabbed.  She uses this a few times and the result leaves behind a pretty bloody mess.  This all leads to some pretty fantastic fights and I am all here for it.That being said, this show does have some holes within it\'s story.  Generally, the story does a decent job at explaining things that happen in the world via Menou, but for the things that she doesn\'t know, the show really leaves it up to us to figure out.  Sometimes it\'s shown, and sometimes it just leaves it hidden to us.  One part in particular that I didn\'t love is what specifically the king does with the people he summons that he wants to keep around.  They really didn\'t go into it at all and that\'s really the basis of the show.  They also revealed to us a pretty interesting bit of story at the end that leaves the show open to return.  I hope it does because that\'s a pretty neat teaser of what\'s to come.  (8/10)Characters: Characters are generally strong throughout the runtime, with no real weak spots that I can think of.Menou is devoted to her job as an executioner and has a pretty good handle on her spells.  She was rescued from a pretty dire situation from Flare, another executioner, and under her study, earned herself the nickname, Flarette.  We aren\'t given much on Flare, but I could see her having a larger role in the story should it continue.  Like Flare, she can unleash some pretty devastating spells, but it\'s mentioned a few times that Menou\'s ether capacity, the fuel for her spells, is rather low.  I actually really like this from both an entertainment and story perspective.  The former, because it keeps fights short and to the point, and the latter because it keeps our expectations fairly leveled.  Menou isn\'t some overpowered being and this limits what she can do.  We\'re given small snippets about Menou\'s past, but not a ton of her inner feelings towards both her situation, and Akari, which would have added a lot.Akari is summoned from Japan and has a power that seems to have pretty devastating effects, should it be used correctly.  She\'s a bit of an airhead, but never gets annoying enough that it gets on my nerves.  She seems to have a different persona going on, but it\'s not touched on too heavily, and is yet another plot point that I would like to see further expanded on in the future.  Momo is Menou\'s devoted retainer who packs quite a punch on her own.  Interestingly, she uses wire as her main weapon and seems to be very good at adapting to the fights in front of her.  Ashuna is a princess to the kingdom of Grisarika, if memory serves, and has a very outward and bold personality.  She isn\'t your typical princess though, and she prefer to fight things head on with her large blade and solid magical prowess - though most seem to revolved around the fire element.  I loved her inclusion, as she\'s committed to her duties and refuses to stand back.Villains in the series mostly come out of nowhere, but I actually liked them because it wasn\'t the typical "take over the world" storyline.  They have clear goals in mind and will do what they need to in order to get there.  They aren\'t the deepest, but their desires do conflict with Menou, and I enjoyed watching as she attempted to stop them.  (8/10)Art: I was very impressed with the animation.  J.C. Staff have put out some decent works and this one doesn\'t falter.  The fights were really solid and the spells always looked fantastic.  The CG is a bit hit or miss, but was generally not an eyesore, which is all you can ask sometimes.  I also like that they don\'t really shy away from the violence either, as we\'ve seen some series try and hide it, and it simply looks unnatural.  (9/10)Sound: I had no real problems with any of the tracks, though the OP, Paper Bouquet by Mili, was a strong inclusion.  VAs were solid, as always, so no problems there either.  (8/10)Overall Enjoyment: The Executioner and Her Way of Life was a solid entry in this completely bonkers anime season that includes a lot of real winners, and I feel like this one doesn\'t get the attention it deserves because of certain people\'s expectations, as well as the other big names airing right now.  You\'re not viewing this as a girls\' love series.  It\'s just a fun, fantasy series with magic and plenty of action.  Keep that in mind, and I think this series would appear to anyone looking for scratch that fantasy itch.  (8/10) summoned, known as Special Concepts, but if the king deems them useless for his purposes, he basically abandons them and throws them into the open world. Keep that in mind, and I think this series would appear to anyone looking for scratch that fantasy itch.  (8/10)', 'TL;DR Shit is kinda boring until episode 6, then it gets real ham to make up for all of that. Some parts are cringy or boring, fine. But it makes up for it with good moments in between and a lot of s2 potential.The first half of the show admittedly is very weak. I\'m not surprised people dismissed this as edgy yuri or whatever. We\'ve seen many twists on the isekai/fantasy genre for years now, so yes, I was also one of the skeptical people just doubting whether or not this was just capitalizing on edgy shock value. On episode 5, when they revealed Orwell...was behind all the shenanigans, I was like, "I\'m literally gonna drop it after this episode if nothing good happens".But the wait was worth it, since shit goes DOWN in episode 6, and only keeps getting better from there, mainly because we become aware of the extent that Akari is manipulating the world. I was hooked from there - a lot of mystery about the world, what Flare is up to, how events are changing, the Astral Archive, where pure concepts are, how that connects back to Japan, etc.I\'m expecting the author to capitalize heavily on all of it. There\'s a lot of interesting material here.The writing could definitely use more work - if there weren\'t so many interesting plot threads hanging by the end, I\'d give it like a 6 - not generic trash, but not good. Some of it was too cheesy, too predictable, too edgy, etc. but whatever, writers aren\'t perfect. I\'m surprised an idea this thoughtful was executed in the first place and didn\'t turn into a convoluted train wreck, unlike some other shows...The art could use some work in some places - for example, episode 8 was a ??? moment for me, and the CGI looked kinda ridiculous. I get it though - animation is hard, and this isn\'t a well known show yet so the funding was limited. In other parts though, it was quite amazing, which I\'ll discuss in the Enjoyment section. 7/10 overall.I really liked the OP and some of the OST\'s, so sound gets an 8 for me.The characters were alright - 7/10. Everyone is kind of generic but it\'s whatever - they were fun to watch, but predictable. The two people that stood out the most were Akari and PandemoniumAkari definitely is carrying here, which makes sense since she\'s kind of like the world\'s god ATM - I\'m interested to see just how more twisted the real Akari is, although it\'s clear she\'s fucked herself up badly already to get away from her memories in Japan.Pandemonium though, holy shit. She acted damn near perfect for her role as a chaos god of sorts. It\'s clear she doesn\'t give a shit about killing or being killed, both because she\'s confident that no one CAN kill her and that she only has limited time to cause havoc anyways.Normally in anime, you see these kinds of gods propped up only to be beaten by the mortals and then the lesson is that humans can subdue god and they should be nicer or something. Nope, not here. Completely reinforces the fear of Pure Concepts and Human Errors, if they couldn\'t even kill a tiny sliver of her. She isn\'t even afraid of Akari\'s time travel abilities, is how powerful and confident she is. Really sets the tone for s2.Enjoyment was 9/10. I think this was what really kept me going, because even if I feel like the show has a lot of potential, it wouldn\'t help if everything else was kinda bog standard. But there\'s just so many cool moments in between - for example:- Menou jumping back from Orwell and immidiately churching her, like damn bro.- Menou\'s dagger and bubble tricks vs Ashuka- Menou stopping Manon from killing Akari by throwing the dagger then jumping out the windowOverall, was 8/10. It was a very solid show with weak writing at times, but a lot of potential and memorable highlights outweigh the negatives IMO. I felt guilty about giving it this high of a score, but then I look at Rikekoi and see that it\'s still sitting at 7.5... yeah, this is at least 8/10 if fucking rikekoi is 7.5. was behind all the shenanigans, I was like, "I\'m literally gonna drop it after this episode if nothing good happens".But the wait was worth it, since shit goes DOWN in episode 6, and only keeps getting better from there, mainly because we become aware of the extent that Akari is manipulating the world. I think this was what really kept me going, because even if I feel like the show has a lot of potential, it wouldn\'t help if everything else was kinda bog standard. But there\'s just so many cool moments in between - for example:- Menou jumping back from Orwell and immidiately churching her, like damn bro.- Menou\'s dagger and bubble tricks vs Ashuka- Menou stopping Manon from killing Akari by throwing the dagger then jumping out the windowOverall, was 8/10. It was a very solid show with weak writing at times, but a lot of potential and memorable highlights outweigh the negatives IMO. I felt guilty about giving it this high of a score, but then I look at Rikekoi and see that it\'s still sitting at 7.5... yeah, this is at least 8/10 if fucking rikekoi is 7.5.', 'It\'s a show about some magic and some bullshit with an episode 1 "twist" at the end that kinda tells you all you really need to know about the show and its plot. I\'d like to say I wanna finish it but I really don\'t as the show plays all its cards early, like someone who thinks they\'re good at uno but drops every wildcard and +2/+4 they have as soon as they draw them. The twists are foreshadowed with the subtlety of a brick through your kitchen window.As far as Isekai shows go, its not the worst thing ever and its at least...got interesting ideas and premises unlike most of the generic garbage that the genre has to offer, but it treads similar paths, almost like instead of walking directly in the footprints of its forefathers it rides a sick 8 speed bike with flames painted on the side through the already blazed trails, while other good shows drive by in their dodge chargers. It\'s just not dark enough to satisfy and not nearly as cool as it thinks it is. got interesting ideas and premises unlike most of the generic garbage that the genre has to offer, but it treads similar paths, almost like instead of walking directly in the footprints of its forefathers it rides a sick 8 speed bike with flames painted on the side through the already blazed trails, while other good shows drive by in their dodge chargers. It\'s just not dark enough to satisfy and not nearly as cool as it thinks it is.', 'Despite being an Isekai, you gotta give credit to Shokei Shoujo for its originality. Having what seems to be a standard Isekai suddenly turn into a yuri romance-adventure tale not 10 minutes into the first episode certainly is surprising...that is if you didn\'t read the description, watched any of the trailers, or even took a look at the key visual. But I am getting ahead of myself. Shokei Shoujo is still ultimately a fine show, and that much I am willing to say, but I wished it was much more than this.Part of this stems from being an incomplete adaptation of an ongoing light novel....The difference between a good LN adaptation and a bad one is knowing where to stop. I understand it\'s rare for a complete adaptation of something several volumes long, but Shokei Shoujo just ends on a sequel hook that left a sour note on my viewing experience once all is said and done. All these plot points they brought up certainly were interesting, but the show went nowhere close to resolving either of them nor is the final episode a good enough cap off to the series. I suppose as an ad for the LN it did work, I went ahead and bought the damn books so I can continue reading more on Menou and Akari\'s yuri adventures.As an adaptation it does its job. JC really needs to stop taking so many projects per season. Shokei Shoujo is mostly dialogue so the animation quality is mostly fine, but the action scenes are all fairly flaccid with a few exceptions here and there, most notably Momo punching that monster somewhere in the middle of the series. One would think most of their budget/manpower went to Shamiko\'s show instead. Credit where credit is due though, the anime\'s interpretation of the spell casting sequence from the LNs is presented incredibly well; it\'s just so slick and it really made me wish the same attention was paid for the main bulk of the action sequences as well.Really everything else about this anime is just that. Fine. The music is fine, I love the OP and ED, and the OST does use some rare instruments here and there to spice things up, but all in all it\'s there and it\'s just fine. The characters are fine, Akari and Momo are really fun to follow, but Menou is a tad too dull for my tastes. And then there is the story. For all of its successes in building a believable, original world, the ultimate story that is conveyed in the anime is "Menou brings Akari somewhere to kill her". Nothing too important happens outside of the main duo, and the viewer,  learning more about the world and themselves. And again, there are interesting elements being teased, but at this point it\'s just like dangling a shiny object in front of the viewers when the payoff is all in the LNs.For a time in my life I generally avoided LN adaptations because I don\'t like the feeling of watching an incomplete story only for the outcome to be in a novel in a language I don\'t understand, but these days I\'ve started to enjoy quite a few of them, but the ones I do enjoy generally have low stakes plot that are fine without a total and complete resolution. Not so in this case. After the end of the series I just feel empty inside, and I\'m not sure if that\'s a problem with the modern climate these shows are made in, where it\'s a struggle to even get more than a single cour, or the way the show was structured in the first place. In any case, perhaps it\'s time for me to start reading Shokei Shoujo. At least the translations seem to be relatively punctual...6/10 The difference between a good LN adaptation and a bad one is knowing where to stop. In any case, perhaps it\'s time for me to start reading Shokei Shoujo. At least the translations seem to be relatively punctual...6/10', "Once you take away all of the superfluous and cheap plot details that fly at you to make sure that you’re still engaged and strip the story to its bare bones, all you’re left with is a very typical shounen story. What I really mean is that the story boils down to a generic assassin girl with a tragic backstory that’s been trained since she was little, starts to develop feelings for her target, one way or the other, and the entire story is the romance/friendship that emerges from this what used to be a target. I imagine this type of story is familiar, or...rings some bells?For all of the people that say this show is different because it’s “dark” and edgy. You’re kidding me right? The entire narrative of the story, from Menou’s backstory, to her monologues, her dialogue and relationship with Akari, and the story arcs that the show shoves you into is meant to frame Menou as a tragic hero that’s doing what’s only right to save humanity. In the end, the show isn’t even edgy.Don’t worry, you’re on the good side still, the story makes sure to have that happen. I’m not going to go super philosophical on this show. There’s not much reason to. Is Menou an actual good person, even though she kills innocent people? Well, with all of the entire show’s premise, setting, and story coming together to support Menou being a “good person,'' then she probably is a good person. The entire show intentionally gives you shock value, edginess, a tragic backstory, and an act of murder to paint a morally diametric character to give some depth, but this theme is so underdeveloped and later on, just forgotten in favor of redundant plot points.This show really makes me appreciate a well done edgy show, like Attack on Titan. Before you stop reading my review because you hate Attack on Titan or something: hear me out. Attack on Titan has similar edgy themes, in which there are moral decisions that people need to make in the show that are diametrically opposed. The difference between this show and AoT is that it doesn’t shove into your face that the MC is good. In fact, it does kind of the opposite. The story sides against the MC. No, you’re really supposed to explore the reasons for both sides of the conflict. AoT does a brilliant job of that compared to any other edgy show, including this one. Instead of BS like “the friends we made along the way” trumps the actual goal, the show actually makes the moral conflict the main focus of the entire story.This show merely dabbles in its moral themes and as a result, feels extremely shallow and hollow. Let’s just disparage any sort of themes that the show may have, and instead, let’s just have Menou and Akari have fun! Or how about fan-service? Of course a good story has to have that. LMAO, after brutally killing someone, Momo’s like, “I’m so jealous of boob-woman!!!! :(((“. Wow, I’m really getting drawn into the story when every other scene is something cringe right out of a harem rom-com. Or how about the pathetic attempts at trying to make Menou a good person? Oh, look, she’s saving the people in the train, and she’s also beating the corrupt organization. Gee, thanks, I’m so glad you’re giving her scenarios in which she’s undisputedly the good person.No, despite the “heavy” and edgy themes in play, most of the show is just mindless conflict, dialogue and “CRAZY PLOT REVEALS” all the way to episode 12 that just drag the story in muddy waters. It’s like the only thing this show is trying to do is make drag on your attention span that much longer. The more explaining that this show does of random plot points that become essential to the main story like “oh yeah, being X is at play here, you’re not going to win,” the more the show gets dragged away from it’s initial premise. With the introduction of new, shiny characters and plot points, it’s just begging the viewer to keep watching so you figure out what is actually happening. The show is edgy, shock value, and eventually devolves into the most typical shounen imaginable. rings some bells?For all of the people that say this show is different because it’s “dark” and edgy. You’re kidding me right? The entire narrative of the story, from Menou’s backstory, to her monologues, her dialogue and relationship with Akari, and the story arcs that the show shoves you into is meant to frame Menou as a tragic hero that’s doing what’s only right to save humanity. The show is edgy, shock value, and eventually devolves into the most typical shounen imaginable.", 'So I gave this a 7/10 review... Also this review is for the DUB version. Please note, many of us are dyslexic, can have issues reading sub while trying to appreciate the art of the shows.So, Sadly I had to downgraded it by 2 points.  This would be due the absolute dismal voice acting, I had flashbacks of most the Netflix Dubs.  Brittany is a S Tier VA, so what happened here.  She was almost nauseating to listen to. Her gasping for air every time she spoke drove me nuts. Momo was a really good character, and if not for...her compulsive stalker mentality, easy would have been a fan favorite.So, how did I even give it 7 stars... STORY STROY STORY.  Very well done and creative story and I would love to see the direction we are heading.  I encourage you to watch this, sub if you can, dub if like me you must.There are other reviews that are very off base of why this anime is not more popular. Their Dubs are often poorly directed and converted.', 'If I were to describe this anime in 1 sentence it would be "The antithesis to shounen battle anime". I found this series rather enjoyable to watch. Also, it is definitely worth watching just for the fact that it presents an alternate viewpoint to the common shounen troupes like "I can do it if I try hard enough" or "there is always a way to save everyone". While I won\'t claim that this is the only series that contests that, it does it an extremely elegant way in my opinion. Having said that there are some issues (especially with characters) that don\'t allow this series...to reach its full potential.Story (8/10): Intriguing and engaging to summarize. There is much information that is not revealed to the watcher, which can be a good plot device at times, but I found it to be frustrating at times too.Characters (6/10): There is only 1 main character, (at least in my opinion, MAL seems to disagree haha) Menou. Her character is interesting and thought provoking. However, the development of her character is done rather strangely. It feels as if her character from when she was in training to the present has changed drastically without an obvious trigger (though some educated guesses can be made too much info is missing). The rest of the characters are subpar at best. Akari\'s motivations are not fleshed out properly, which is a shame because she could have been a great character. Momo falls into all the shounen tropes (only that she is a girl). Her dialogue writing seems rather lazy to be honest. She seems to exist only to worship Menou. Most of the other characters are quite single dimensional as well.Art (8/10): The art is nice but nothing special.Overall rating: 7 + 1 (for a unique perspective). Do watch this series at least once, it\'s worth the watch. to reach its full potential.Story (8/10): Intriguing and engaging to summarize. Why did I feel it was necessary to note first? Well, show isn't worth an awful lot outside of that fact. That's probably the most important part.The whole thing seemed like a really washed out soap opera to me, just with magic. The amount of drama/conflict that exists in this show is completely ridiculous and none of it has any sort of real relevance to the rest of the show. It just shows up when...they're bored. Most of the battles are short-lived and are ended very easily and very quickly by the MC.I guess I can throw a mixed feelings on this, but this is definitely one of those shows that I wish that I hadn't taken a time to watch but might be somebody else's perfect score. they're bored. Most of the battles are short-lived and are ended very easily and very quickly by the MC.I guess I can throw a mixed feelings on this, but this is definitely one of those shows that I wish that I hadn't taken a time to watch but might be somebody else's perfect score.", '***THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS***Isekai is an undeniably popular genre for Japanese works. It’s become so common that it has a few formulas and even some prejudice about how it can be a little generic.The story follows Menou, an Executioner working for The Faust (the church of this world) who is tasked with killing ‘Otherworlders’. Her world has suffered many disasters thanks to Otherworlders, humans who have been summoned from Japan and gained powerful abilities upon reaching this new world. Now The Faust have taken it upon themselves to kill any Otherworlders who are summoned before their powers fully manifest.The trouble is the nobles of this...world are obsessed with power and see the Otherworlders as a way for them to become stronger than their neighboring countries. Before killing her target, Menou first attempts to make them trust her to find out if their power will be any hindrance to the assassination. This gives her the ability to carry out her task without getting into chaotic battles, but it also ends up being a big benefit in her next mission… Menou’s latest task is to kill a girl called Akari, but while Menou thinks Akari’s power is simply to heal, she quickly discovers that Akari actually has the power to turn back time if she’s fatally wounded. Luckily for Menou, Akari retains no memory of having been killed so Menou can at least pretend to be her friend while working out how to get rid of her once and for all.Outside of Menou killing one Otherworlder, the majority of the story is taken up by her dealing with Akari. Because Menou’s assassination attempts fail, she’s invited back to one of the headquarters for The Faust where they’re said to have more powerful magic that can be used to kill Otherworlders. This means that Menou and Akari will now be traveling together for a short while, which Akari is excited about. Menou has told her that they’re going to The Faust to send her back to Japan, so for now, she doesn’t suspect a thing. Meanwhile, Menou is starting to grow attached to the girl, which may pose problems later when it comes to saying goodbye… The Executioner and Her Way of Life certainly has an interesting premise with the idea of a world so torn apart from Otherworlders that they need to start killing them upon arrival.Menou also makes for a compelling protagonist. She’s been through a disaster all of her own which left her orphaned, resulting in her being taken in by the church, but she’s also not weak. She’s very serious by nature but there is a kind personality here, which is brought out by having Akari around. We also get to see her dote on her subordinate Momo plenty, which adds to the depth of her character. Akari for her part is more stereotypical in terms of being a happy-go-lucky Japanese high-school student who is fascinated by the new world she’s found herself in.It’s also interesting that the series leans into being a Yuri in places, with both Akari and Momo clearly being very attached to Menou, and it will be interesting to see if the author does anything with that in future volumes. The illustrations (handled by nilitsu) certainly lean into the idea of the series being a Girls’ Love of some description, so that element is likely here to stay.Overall, The Executioner and Her Way of Life is an extremely likable anime. It is worth spending your if you’re looking for a spin on the isekai genre! world are obsessed with power and see the Otherworlders as a way for them to become stronger than their neighboring countries. The illustrations (handled by nilitsu) certainly lean into the idea of the series being a Girls’ Love of some description, so that element is likely here to stay.Overall, The Executioner and Her Way of Life is an extremely likable anime. It is worth spending your if you’re looking for a spin on the isekai genre!', "Shokei Shoujo no Virgin Road is bottom of the barrel light novel Isekai garbage that tries to hide the fact that's its not through a premise that seems to be interesting at first, but holds all of the hallmarks of an anime in this genre: awful writing, horrible animation, and women with large breasts.The premise is actually fairly interesting on its own: in the world of Shokei Shoujo no Virgin Road, isekai'd japanese highschoolers are gifted special powers that, instead of giving them a giant harem, threaten to run out of control and cause giant calamities if left unchecked, so it falls to members...of the church (Faust) to kill them before this happens. Menou, the PoV character, is one of these members, and the plot details her journey in order to kill the isekai'd Akari, who has the power to reverse time. The plot that comes after this is sort of boring, both of the 'arcs' feel both too slow and resolve to quickly.The actual world is... confusing. The dialogue is written like the author (and whoever wrote the script) didn't actually know how to properly introduce the world through the narrative, so characters will constantly just spit out exposition during dialogue. Every single character will randomly add expository summaries of the world even though the character they are talking to obviously knows what it is so they can tell the aduience. It's like some steampunk-magic-ether type bullshit that doesn't really make any sense under scrutiny and really feels like a combination of shit the LN author thought was cool. The actual line to dialogue is just banal too. The world has more to it then the average isekai show, but for me that makes it more disappointing when it fails to deliver.Speaking of disappointment, the animation is godawful. The direction is extremely flat and boring. Like a lot of low budget shows of this ilk, most of the show is still/panning shots of characters standing around and talking. When the characters have to move, they do so sparingly, and when they move for more than five seconds it breaks down. The animators clearly had no time to storyboard the fight scenes, so the choreography is weird and fights are usually just a giant mess of janky animation, random events that don't flow together, and characters standing around and talking all with shitty cgi ether lighting effects over everything. And like every other anime in this genre, it does indeed feature a poorly done giant cgi monster.For the good... The background art is half decent? The soundtrack is also above average for an anime; its not something I would go out of my way to listen to but it makes some scenes better, which is a rarity in this industry. The OP is also great, but thats because Mili is a good artist.These types of shows really frustrate me because it's clear that the source material has some interesting ideas, but because its one of hundreds of LN adaptation isekai shows released yearly, its stuck with an awful production quality due to it's shoestring budget and extreme time constrictions.Can people either stop making these shows or put actual money and talent into them? of the church (Faust) to kill them before this happens. The OP is also great, but thats because Mili is a good artist.These types of shows really frustrate me because it's clear that the source material has some interesting ideas, but because its one of hundreds of LN adaptation isekai shows released yearly, its stuck with an awful production quality due to it's shoestring budget and extreme time constrictions.Can people either stop making these shows or put actual money and talent into them?", 'Fool them thrice and no more! Overpowered protagonist?  The religion of this world solved that problem after the errors of letting them run wild in the first place... An Anti-Isekai worth attention in an oversaturated market of generic attempts. In this world you don\'t get to be the summoned hero. The summoned are to be despised for their "gifts." This is a wildly unique story of a heroine desperate to complete her mission in accordance with her faith and our absent minded guest attempting to help in any way. What you will watch is a battle of conflicting interests. This is a standout from...the standard, "copy and paste and then fill in the blanks" Isekai. This anime does not deserve the hate. This a very fresh take on  Isekai. For those who want a great and different twist to the mundane, then this does it better than anything I’ve seen.  The haters should love to hate it. the standard, "copy and paste and then fill in the blanks" Isekai. This anime does not deserve the hate. This a very fresh take on  Isekai. For those who want a great and different twist to the mundane, then this does it better than anything I’ve seen.  The haters should love to hate it.', "tl;dr akame ga kill meets re:zero, but not enough of eitherAfter I finished this show I felt a notable lack of emotion. I say notable because Shokei Shoujo makes it painfully obvious from episode one that it's supposed to be a mature anime, for perhaps a relatively older audience than most isekais, and that it's supposed to introduce some interesting food for thought. Yet having spent four hours of my life viewing this anime, I don't feel like I've gained anything other than a minor headache and a slightly better understanding of kanji.The show really throws you into the thick of it from episode one...and for the first couple episodes the pacing and story is great. It looks like the viewer is going to be set up for a strong season with conflict within the main character, Menou, as well as conflict without as she and her companions are constantly pitted against the relentless forces of corruption, avarice, and plain pure evil.Skip this next paragraph if you don't want minor spoilers.However, I can tell you the exact moment where the show loses steam though in the interest of minimizing spoilage I will only say that the foreshadowing is too strong and what I think should have been the real climax between Menou's wishes and personality and her church-bound training came far, far too soon and thus set up what felt to me like a falling action throughout the rest of the season.Resume non-spoilage.Side character development is non-existant. Main character too for that matter. Menou is too strongly rooted in her beliefs that what she is doing is right and she has somehow justified it to herself that it is the only way forward. The question about if what she's doing is right isn't seriously asked; the answer is always yes invariably. None of the side characters get in any pinches with hard questions either. Akari almost does but she really just gives a cop-out answer and the show leaves it at that since timing I guess.One plus was the lines and lines of invoke magic we got. I really liked those visuals and seeing the magic as kanji script so that was a plus for me. Unfortunately the actual character animation was a bit... simplistic? And I personally didn't like either the OP or ED.I guess to summarize, Shokei Shoujo stormed out the gate and proceeded to lose all that steam, becoming a worse-than-average voyage/journey anime with few difficult moments and challenging propositions to back up what the first couple episodes laid down. Worth a watch as a third-line anime perhaps. and for the first couple episodes the pacing and story is great. It looks like the viewer is going to be set up for a strong season with conflict within the main character, Menou, as well as conflict without as she and her companions are constantly pitted against the relentless forces of corruption, avarice, and plain pure evil.Skip this next paragraph if you don't want minor spoilers.However, I can tell you the exact moment where the show loses steam though in the interest of minimizing spoilage I will only say that the foreshadowing is too strong and what I think should have been the real climax between Menou's wishes and personality and her church-bound training came far, far too soon and thus set up what felt to me like a falling action throughout the rest of the season.Resume non-spoilage.Side character development is non-existant. Main character too for that matter. Menou is too strongly rooted in her beliefs that what she is doing is right and she has somehow justified it to herself that it is the only way forward. The question about if what she's doing is right isn't seriously asked; the answer is always yes invariably. None of the side characters get in any pinches with hard questions either. Akari almost does but she really just gives a cop-out answer and the show leaves it at that since timing I guess.One plus was the lines and lines of invoke magic we got. I really liked those visuals and seeing the magic as kanji script so that was a plus for me. Unfortunately the actual character animation was a bit... simplistic? And I personally didn't like either the OP or ED.I guess to summarize, Shokei Shoujo stormed out the gate and proceeded to lose all that steam, becoming a worse-than-average voyage/journey anime with few difficult moments and challenging propositions to back up what the first couple episodes laid down. Worth a watch as a third-line anime perhaps.", "I've watched all of them, but I don't think there's anything special, why? Because there are many storylines on the market, I've often seen stories that are almost th Other anime.When it comes to quality, I really like it because the images that are made clearly and in detail by this studio don't disappoint the audience, it's just that I can't make it a waifu Because of the storyline problem that I have explained above.For each character is good I think.What disappointed me was the initial concept that was lost, As if the executor's name was just a cover and not the core of the...storyline Because when you meet a girl who can't be killed, the storyline changes drastically and all you have is adventure But I might not be able to turn it on because if you look at the title and genre of this anime, it's an adventure But I, as a spectator, will definitely be consumed by the initial concept, which is that as an executor, he switches jobs to become a courier for delivering girls to be killed.The most complicated thing in this story is that the main character has to deal with time magic users, and like most other anime, time magic users are the most troublesome because He can go back in time as if nothing happened storyline Because when you meet a girl who can't be killed, the storyline changes drastically and all you have is adventure But I might not be able to turn it on because if you look at the title and genre of this anime, it's an adventure But I, as a spectator, will definitely be consumed by the initial concept, which is that as an executor, he switches jobs to become a courier for delivering girls to be killed.The most complicated thing in this story is that the main character has to deal with time magic users, and like most other anime, time magic users are the most troublesome because He can go back in time as if nothing happened", 'SHOKEI SHOUJO NO VIRGIN ROADShokei Shoujo is an interesting isekai anime. Its world is one that is so used to the isekai phenomenon that the reincarnated Japanese people have already influenced the culture and way of life of those in the isekai world. So much so that they even have historically significant encounters with certain otherworlders that has led to catastrophic events at times. These dangers has sprung the need for executioners that eliminate otherworlders in order to prevent more future disasters.Shokei Shoujo focuses on the executioner Menou and her encounter with Akari, an otherworlder reincarnated with an extremely powerful time manipulating True Concept (this...world\'s name for their powers). Along with her time powers came the complication that she is unable to be killed with traditional methods. This leads to their journey together to find a way to kill Akari before her powers get out of control.STORY - 9/10As someone who is not a big fan of isekai, I enjoyed this one very much. It seemed fresh and unique compared to the usual OP male isekai protagonist as the main cast are mostly female members. With Menou serving as an executioner looking to find a way to eliminate her target, Akari, they embark on their journey together where their relationship develops and secrets are unfolded.The lore and world of Shokei Shoujo is quite impressive. With the history imbedded into its story and the various land and city scapes, one can definitely feel the immersion. The magic system is also extremely interesting and something that you just want to see and know more of. My favorite thing about the story would probably be the pacing. For a 12-episode season, Shokei Shojou was able to effectively have 2 major arcs concluding with 2 major showdowns all without feeling too rushed or too slow. Along with the excellent pacing is the slow yet fulfilling unraveling of the secrets of this world and of Akari\'s powers.ART & SOUND - 7.5/10The art of Shokei Shojou is generally okay. Aside from the cool magic effects and fighting animation, character design isn\'t anything too special or unique. I love the casting animations of spells, though. I think they are super cool. Add to that the mechanical-like sound effects when casting, it makes for a very badass and satisfying feeling when watching characters cast their spells. Why it gets a mediocre 7.5 would be the animation of the final "boss". The CGI-esque (I\'m not sure if it actually is CGI animated) look of the centipede version of Pandemonium just left an extremely bitter taste in my mouth. It looked out of place and ruined what could have been an epic conclusion in my opinion.CHARACTERS - 8/10The characters are all very lovable and enjoyable. Their varied traits all complement each other for a fun dynamic with their relationships. Menou\'s calculated and cold aura, Akari\'s carefree nature, and Momo\'s loyalty make for an interesting dynamic between the 3 main heroines. Add to that the Princess\' fiery bloodlust and you have a fun cast of characters. The villains are also noteworthy as they have understandable motives, especially Manon who you can\'t help but actually feel bad for.ENJOYMENT - 8/10Overall, a very solid, fresh, and unique isekai fantasy with interesting characters and an intriguing overarching story and mystery. Engaging and dynamic fight scenes paired with a very cool magic system keeps the action pumping and the viewers entertained. Mix it up with some fun and charming banter between the characters and you have yourself a fun watch.OVERALL - 7.5/10This would have easily been a very solid 8 if it weren\'t for the CGI centipede for the finale. I really did not enjoy it and it left a bitter taste in my mouth of an otherwise very entertaining isekai. world\'s name for their powers). Along with her time powers came the complication that she is unable to be killed with traditional methods. This leads to their journey together to find a way to kill Akari before her powers get out of control.STORY - 9/10As someone who is not a big fan of isekai, I enjoyed this one very much. I really did not enjoy it and it left a bitter taste in my mouth of an otherwise very entertaining isekai.', 'Great anime, a very different anime from isekai, its insanely interesting and its plot twists managed to surprise and shock even me even though im very experienced with anime and i know what to expect from watching basically any anime but this one gave even me some unexpected twists. I strongly recommend this aniime, i really enjoyed it and I hope and cant wait for second season because the first one was amazing, ofc there were some things that could have been written better but it doesnt mean its bad because theres no anime in the world thats flawless thats why il still give this...a 10! a 10!', "The art in this anime is pleasing to the eyes and its characters are interesting enough (personalitywise) but the problem for me at least is the story. I felt like it was trying too hard to be an isekai different from other isekai and in doing so the story itself ended up with sloppy loose ends.Tbh the first episode of this series shouldn't exist and by that I mean it was a waste of time. It didn't do anything to the story except show what Menou does as her job and what it entails but I could've learned that through normal means like dialog. The...point was for viewers to understand what Menou does as an Executioner. The problem is that at least for me all it did was leave me with a bad taste in my mouth that I couldn't get rid of and it ended up ruining most of my experience watching the show.Let me explain in the first episode you're introduced to Mutou Mitsuki who's just an average student summoned to another world your typical isekai plot. I'm sure you already guess what happens to him from reading the synopsis of the anime. The point is I felt like I didn't need them to build up a fake mc like this it wasted my time investing into his character just to show me what Menou does as an Executioner because I would've figured out anyway by watching the rest of the episode. Also Mutou's power is strong but apparently it only affects the area around him and does not prevent things from happing to him which doesn't make much sense considering what his powers are but I won't spoil it. They really wasted a very good character on a story build that didn't need to be built. It would have been a better story had they used his character in a different way instead of being just fodder for introducing the real mc of the story.In the end, Mutou is just another character that was trashed and he doesn't comeback meaning they wasted a good character that could've spiced up the story in a good way just for a very bland point to be made which could've been made at any time hence why I believe episode 1 was a waste of time and shouldn't have been made at all. I would've enjoyed the series more had the first episode been the second episode instead I was left with a bad taste of a good character being written off for a dumb reason and a bland story full of holes that made it look like swiss cheese. The only redeemable quality of the show is the art style and the characters' personalities which couldn't be enjoyed to its fullest because the story wasn't there and it would sometimes conflict with the characters' personalities.If your looking for a different type of isekai with a compelling story then this most likely isn't for you but if the story isn't what really matters to you then you should give this a watch It's at least good for a one time watch. point was for viewers to understand what Menou does as an Executioner. The concept of "original sin", "the scriptures", or any form of worldbuilding are simply used as jargon and are barely explained in the world.The plot got somewhat interesting with Akari\'s time powers and the interactions between Akari and Menou/Ashura and Momo were nice but definitely not worth sitting through this boring anime.tl;dr, it doesn\'t subvert any expectations and if you do plan on watching it, have very low...expectations. There\'s almost nothing new or interesting about this and while it has the potential to be better, you\'re probably better off just skipping this. expectations. There\'s almost nothing new or interesting about this and while it has the potential to be better, you\'re probably better off just skipping this.', 'This anime took like 3 episodes to convince me I should try and finish it before I was like okay I can keep watching this and enjoy it. I made it to the end of episode 6 and was like "hmmmm 6 more episodes?" Hard pass on that for me. Episode 6 felt like the end of a season to me. What they hinted at being in the following episodes is not my cup of tea.I would recommend the first 6 episodes to anyone. However the last 6 I can\'t recommend because I haven\'t watched them for 1 and for 2 have 0 desire...to watch them. If the writers could hint at the 2nd half being action packed and/or entertaining or basically anything aside from what they hinted at. I would take a stab at 7-12. But simply saying "I WILL find a way to kill this person that doesn\'t necessarily want to die, I have 0 reason to kill after she\'s literally saved my life and many others several times, rewound the world several times while still not going on a rampage as supposedly should\'ve happened several times by now, AND I\'m on good terms with...." yeah big fat NOPE from me.Story wise, crap reason to continue the anime. Illogical, sounds boring, characters quirks already way overdone don\'t want to watch 2 more hours of the same. Also something to note, there is like 0 males in the anime. I mean for all the people tired of male main characters and males having ANY relevance or presence in the story, HERE. YOU. GO. Not going back to check but you have 2 males\' names said like a total of 5 times added together and NO other males names even mentioned a single time. You also see them for about a total of 3-5 minutes combined. Everything else is ALL female characters.Aside from all the negatives this anime had for me if I stick to simply just the 6 episodes I watched and ignore its crap lead into the next few episodes its not a bad anime. Like I said earlier, will be incredibly difficult to convince me to watch the remaining episodes of this anime but everyone should at least give the first 6 episodes a watch. to watch them.
